refnamediv.refpurpose: Communicate with RTS2 XML-RPC daemon. Provides commands to interact with RTS2 through a single HTTP-accessible communication channel.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: &dhpackage; is a test implementation of XMl-RPC protocol used by RTS2. It shares libraries with rts2-httpd7, so it should work when rts2-httpd works.

Apart from being the test implementation, rts2-xmlrpcclient also provides a few handy commands, which retrieve or set RTS2 values. Those commands can be used to interact with RTS2 from the command shell. RTS2 XML-RPC protocol can be used in various high level languages.

refsect1.title: Configuration
refsect1.para: Access to rts2-httpd server is ussually password protected, using either standard HTTP authorization, or custom authorization inside rts2-httpd. There are two options how to provide username and password for HTTP connections. They can be listed on command line, or specified in a configuration file. If you specify username using --user option, rts2-xmlrpcclient will ask for password.
If you specify username and password in a configuration file, the content of the file should look as in an example bellow.
This specify user as username and password as user password.

refentry.refsect1:
OPTIONS
&optiongnu;
-v
Increase verbosity. Multiple -v are possible. Usefull to debug output of XML-RPC commands.
--quiet
Run quiet, don't report errors on stderr. Usefull in scripts, dangerous when running from terminal, as it will suppress possibly usefull messages.
-g
Retrieve values passed on command line and prints them, separated by line feed, on standard output. On input, device and variable name should be separated by .. They are separated by _ on output, so they can be used as system variables names. Suppose that there is device SENSOR, with varibles var1 and var2, and xmlrpcd is running on your computer. Following is sample execution:
user@machine:~$ rts2-xmlrcclient -g SENSOR.var1 SENSOR.var2 SENSOR.var1=12.33 SENSOR.var2=56.34
-G
Similar to -g, but do not print variables names on standard output.
-s device.variable value
Set variables specified on command line. Device name, variable name and value need to be specified. Device name is separated from the variable name with . (colon).
-i device.variable increment
Increment variable(s). Works simirarly to -s, only executes += operation instead of =.
-S device
Get state of device(s) specified as argument. There is an example, assuming SENSOR is present in the environment:
user@machine:~$ rts2-xmlrcclient -S SENSOR SENSOR 0 sensor 0
-c device.command
Executes commandi(s) on the given device. The executed commands are standard RTS2 system commands, which are either documented in the components (devices) man pages, or can be found in the source files.
--targets target name
List target(s) matching specifed names. You can use '%' as wildcard. If no name is specifid, all targets in the database are printed.
The matching targets are separated with newlines. The line includes target ID, type, name, and target RA and DEC. Following example list gives resonse to query for target with name M31.
user@machine:~$ rts2-xmlrpcclient --targets M31 1001 79 M31 00:42:44.350 +41:16:08.63
--master-state on|off|standby|rnight
Get master state either as a number, or as 0/1 respons to query if the state is on(ready), standby, off or ready night (rnight argument). Following is an example, asking whenever system is in on state - reply 1 means it is (0 would mean it is not):
user@machine:~$ rts2-xmlrcclient --master-state on 1
--hostname XML-RPCd host
Specify XML-RPCd hostname.
--port XML-RPCd port number
Specify port on which XML-RPCd listen to incoming requests. Default to 8889.
--user
Specify user login. User password must be specified from terminal. If you would like to automatise logins, you can place user credentials in configuration file, specified with --config.
--config config file
Specify configuration file. The configuration file can hold user credentials.
